Author: StevenB_06

Comment: Et tu, Brute? When Julius Caesar was stabbed to death, that was part of a much broader plot against him. But when his buddy Brutus was the one who sealed the deal, Caeser took that more personally because he wasn't expecting betrayal from folks he thought were his friends.  Simply put, the Dems don't have control over their enemies' behavior. That's what makes them enemies. Of course losing the House is a bigger deal, but it's pretty reasonable for the Dems to be more frustrated about folks within the party blocking what they CAN do than about the other party doing what is expected.

Author: TheFairyingForest

Comment: What’s the benefit for the Dems to remove the filibuster now? The previous point of removing it is to pass more progressive legislation in the Senate.   But now more progressive legislation won’t get picked up in the house, and if the GOP retakes the Senate in 2 years, they’ll be able to pass more conservative legislation with only 50 votes.   Ideally, the Dems would have wanted simple majority voting early in Biden’s presidency. Then they could have passed voting rights stuff to ease disenfranchisement and make it easier for them to remain in power.

Comment: Oh there is no IF the gop most likely WILL take the senate in 2024, the 2024 senate map just looks to good for republicans, democrats will be defending senate seats in states like Montana, Ohio and West Virginia which isn’t good news for democrats they will have to compete in normally red states in a year that is most likely going to favor the gop especially if someone like DeSantis becomes the republican nominee for president.  The best thing democrats can easily do the next 2 years is solidify their gains in states that are trending towards them like Arizona or Georgia and expand in those states. However I don’t see a real reality where democrats keep the senate past 2024 they would have to keep Ohio, Montana and West Virginia while defend in a number of other swing states.
